pullRequest.body:
---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]
-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

Hello. This PR is marked `awaiting-review` as I am not certain whether lemmas of this nature should go in Mathlib or Std. I would want to check before adding more list lemmas—some of which depend on this one. I believe I have this lemma placed in a reasonable spot in Mathlib—nearby other list-reversing lemmas. The most reasonable spot in Std would be nearby 'disjoint' lemmas in Data/List/Lemmas.lean. 

I am following Eric's suggestion that it is ok to PR data structure lemmas to mathlib as they may always be moved later on, as mentioned in discussion here:
https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/287929-mathlib4/topic/Should.20data.20structures.20theory.20sit.20in.20mathlib.3F

Please let me know if there are any issues. Thank you for your patience.

bors merge

It's good to start with a small PR, because annoying people may come along and write more comments than lines of code you've put up for review :)

I hope this is not demotivating, but I found some more general lemmas that would be even more useful and this could build on top of.

It's good to start with a small PR, because annoying people may come along and write more comments than lines of code you've put up for review :)

I hope this is not demotivating, but I found some more general lemmas that would be even more useful and this could build on top of.

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

```suggestion
theorem reverse_disjoint_iff_disjoint (l₁ l₂ : List α) :
```
Also, the name should go from left to right, so `disjoint_reverse...`

If I understand the definition of `List.Disjoint` correctly, we even have `disjoint_reverse_left : Disjoint l₁.reverse l₂ ↔ Disjoint l₁ l₂` and `disjoint_reverse_right : Disjoint l₁ l₂.reverse ↔ Disjoint l₁ l₂`. So maybe we should have both of those, and mark them as simp. I don't know if at that point we still want `disjoint_reverse_reverse : Disjoint l₁.reverse l₂.reverse ↔ Disjoint l₁ l₂`.

In fact, `List.Disjoint` should then be invariant under any permutation: 
```lean
theorem List.Perm.disjoint_left {l₁ l₂ l : List α} (p : List.Perm l₁ l₂) : Disjoint l₁ l ↔ Disjoint l₂ l := sorry
```
And then you can use `List.reverse_perm` to prove the ones about `List.reverse` quickly.

A shorter proof is
```suggestion
    Disjoint l₁ l ↔ Disjoint l₂ l := by
  simp_rw [List.disjoint_left, p.mem_iff]
```
One trick here is to notice that if you rewrite a lemma in both directions in the two branches, you probably didn't want to split in two in the first place.
Can you add `disjoint_right` too?

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat: the reverse of two lists is disjoint iff the lists are disjoint
